Random-File-Access
In contrast to the C-style file access methods which always take place at the internally controlled current file position, these methods take an additional offset parameter, which directly specifies the file position where the next Read() or Write() operation shall take place.

BOOLEAN Read (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 offset, UINT32 max_count, UINT32 &bytes_read)
BOOLEAN Read (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 offset, UINT32 count)
BOOLEAN ReadStreaming (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count, UINT32 &bytes_read)
BOOLEAN ReadStreamingAsync (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count, StreamingCallback)
BOOLEAN Write (const void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 offset, UINT32 count)
BOOLEAN WriteStreaming (const void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count)
BOOLEAN WriteStreamingAsync (const void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count, StreamingCallback callback_func)
C-Style-File-Access
An APOXI file can be operated similar to how it is done in the C standard library (please refer to the C standard library functions fseek(), ftell(), fread(), and fwrite()). The methods in this group internally control the current file position, which specifies where in the file the next operation takes place. The current file position can be changed with method Seek() and retrieved with method Tell(). The methods to read and write at the current file position are named ReadCur() and WriteCur(). APOXI also supports random access file operations. The two different approaches of accessing a file are totally independent of each other, i.e. the random access methods do not affect the current file position at all.

BOOLEAN ReadCur (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 max_count, UINT32 &bytes_read)
BOOLEAN ReadCur (void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count)
BOOLEAN Seek (INT32 offset, SeekOrigin origin)
UINT32 Tell ()
BOOLEAN WriteCur (const void HUGE *buffer, UINT32 count)

Detailed Description

Client interface and base class for files.

The abstract class File specifies the interface for files stored on a storage device and identified by a path. A File object is to be interpreted as a file handle.

Getting a file

Objects of class File cannot be created by operator new. In order to get a File object, method RootFileSystem::GetFile() has to be called. This method returns a smart-pointer of type FilePtr wrapping a newly created File object. The smart-pointer wrapper takes care for proper destruction of the file object.

Operations

This class defines many methods, we classify some of them into these two categories:

  • Contents operations like reading and writing. Prior to performing contents operations the respective file must be opened. After having finished contents operations the file should be closed. If the file is not explicitly closed, this is done in the destructor.
  • File operations like creating, deleting, renaming, and copying. To perform file operations the file must not be open. This is checked using assertions.

All contents and file operations return a BOOLEAN value:

  • TRUE indicates that the operation was performed successfully and
  • FALSE indicates that an error occurred during execution of the operation.

In case of failure of contents or file operations a call to method GetLastError() returns the error code. In case of success this error code is undefined and therefore GetLastError() should not be called.

Other methods allow for getting and/or setting properties (e.g. filename, pathname, path, modification date, creation date, directory flag) or state information (hidden flag, read-only flag, existence) of the file. These methods also return a BOOLEAN value indicating if the asked information could be retrieved. If it could not be retrieved it means that this kind of information is not supported on the file.

Important notes on writing a file

Improve write performance via initial size

A file always has an actual size. When creating a file with Create() you have to specify the initial size. By specifying a realistic value of how big the file will finally be you push performance of write operations a lot. This is because the file does not have to be enlarged when doing a write beyond the actual file size. Please note that if you do a write beyond the actual size then the file gets automatically resized. Of course the actual size then changes accordingly.

Undefined data in files

It is completely within the responsibility of the programmer to care for all the bytes in the file are written to meaningful values. This has to be done with the Write() method. If the programmer fails in writing all positions in the file, then the positions not written contain undefined data!

MIME type of a file

The MIME type of a file is defined by the extension of its pathname.

Sample on how to create a file

See the following sample function of how a file is usually created:

    static BOOLEAN CreateAudioMpegFile(UINT32 size)
    {
        Pathname pathname("/my_sound_file");

        // Add the file extension for the desired MIME type.
        pathname.AddFileExtension(c_mime_audio_mpeg);

        // Get the "file handle".
        FilePtr file = RootFileSystem::GetFile(pathname, L"ffs");
        if (!file.IsValid()) {
            // Handle out of memory error.
            return FALSE;
        }

        if (file->Exists()) {
            // We can't create an already existing file.
            return FALSE;
        }

        if (!file->Create(size)) {
            // Handle file create error.
            return FALSE;
        }

        // Write to the file...

        if (!file->Close()) {
            // Handle file close error.
            return FALSE;
        }

        return TRUE;
    }

Implementing a derived File class for a new storage device

For implementing a concrete file for a distinct storage device, abstract class File has to be subclassed. By design, a storage device is implemented as a subclass of class StorageDevice and requires its associated file class to be implemented as a subclass of class File. For example, in order to integrate the flash file system into the root file system, class FlashStorageDeviceImp is implemented as subclass of class StorageDevice and the associated files stored on the flash storage device are instances of class FlashFileImp, which is implemented as a subclass of class File.

See also:
RootFileSystem

StorageDevice

FlashStorageDeviceImp

FlashFileImp

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

File::File (  const Pathname &  pathname,
const WString &  device_Id
)  [protected]
 

Creates a file object for pathname located on storage device with storage device ID device_Id.

Parameters:
pathname The pathname of the file.
device_Id The storage device ID of the file.

File::~File (   )  [virtual]
 

The subclass has to close the file if it is still open and free any resources. If the file is a temporary file then this file has been created as a temporary file using RootFileSystem::CreateTempFile() and the associated physical file has to be deleted, too. See FlashFileImp::~FlashFileImp() for a sample implementation.

Member Function Documentation

BOOLEAN File::Accept (  FileVisitor &  visitor  ) 
 

If this file is a valid directory then the file visitor is accepted and TRUE is returned. Accepting the file visitor means that for each file in this directory method Visit() of visitor is called. The file visitor defines the filter for the directory iterator to use and tells if directories themselves should also be visited. If this file is not a valid directory then the visitor can't be accepted and FALSE is returned.

Parameters:
visitor The file visitor which operates on the files iterated over.
See also:
FileVisitor

BOOLEAN File::CancelOperation (   ) 
 

This method allows to cancel an operation which is currently running in chunk mode. It is only possible to cancel operations that run in chunk mode, operations not running in chunk mode block and hence can't be interrupted. If cancellation could be performed, then TRUE is returned. If no chunk mode operation is currently running, or the operation running is blocking, cancellation can not be performed and FALSE is returned. If cancellation succeeds, the operation running returns with FALSE and the error code OperationCancelled is set. Note that in case of a canceled write operation, the contents of the file operated on is then in an undefined state.

BOOLEAN File::Close (   )  [pure virtual]
 

Closes a previously opened file. An overriding method must call this base implementation at the end of its implementation if the file could be closed successfully to assure that the counter of open files gets set properly.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Copy (  const Pathname &  dest_pathname,
const WString &  dest_device_Id = L"rfs",
UINT32  copy_buf_size = c_copy_buf_size
)  [virtual]
 

Copies the contents of this file to a file at pathname dest_pathname on the device specified by dest_device_Id. Pathname dest_pathname specifies an existing directory either with or without a filename. If a filename is not specified then the name of this source file is used as destination filename. If the destination file already exists the method fails. If dest_pathname specifies this file nothing is done and TRUE is returned. This file must exist, must not be a directory and must not be open, otherwise an assertion holds.

Parameters:
dest_pathname The pathname where to copy this file to.
dest_device_Id Specifies the storage device where to copy to default initialized to the root storage device.
copy_buf_size The size of the internally used copy buffer, if used at all. The size of this buffer may significantly affect the performance of this operation.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Reimplemented in RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Copy (  const Path &  dest_path,
UINT32  copy_buf_size = c_copy_buf_size
) 
 

Copies the contents of this file to a file at path dest_path. Path dest_path specifies an existing directory either with or without a filename. If a filename is not specified then the name of this source file is used as destination filename. If the destination file already exists the method fails. If dest_path specifies this file nothing is done and TRUE is returned. This file must exist, must not be a directory and must not be open, otherwise an assertion holds.

Parameters:
dest_path The path where to copy this file to.
copy_buf_size The size of the internally used copy buffer, if used at all. The size of this buffer may significantly affect the performance of this operation.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::CopyContentsTo (  const FilePtr &  dest_file,
UINT32  copy_buf_size
)  [protected]
 

Copies the contents of this file to the destination file dest_file. The destination file must exist and if it is not open yet then it will be opened. As many bytes are copied as fit into the destination file. On success the files are closed explicitly.

Parameters:
dest_file The destination file.
copy_buf_size The size of the internally used copy buffer, if used at all. The size of this buffer may significantly affect the performance of this operation.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::Create (  UINT32  size  )  [pure virtual]
 

Creates a physical file with path m_path and initial size specified in bytes. The MIME type of the file is implicitly defined by the extension of m_path. The file can only be created if it doesn't exist yet. After the file has been created successfully, the file is opened automatically for contents operations in mode ReadAndWriteMode and its internal file position is set to 0, independent of the size argument. The file grows itself if it is written beyond its actual size. Creating an empty file with size 0 is allowed. For shrinking or growing the file use method Resize(). An overriding method must call this base implementation at the end of its implementation if the file could be created successfully to assure that the counter of open files gets set properly. This is a file operation and of course the file must not be open on call.

Parameters:
size The initial size of the new file.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

virtual BOOLEAN File::CreateDir (   )  [pure virtual]
 

Creates a physical directory with path m_path. The last segment of m_path is taken as name of the new directory to create. The directory can only be created if all the directories specified in m_path already exist and the new directory doesn't exist yet. This is a file operation and of course the file must not be open on call.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::CreateStreaming (   )  [pure virtual]
 

Creates a physical file with path m_path. The MIME type of the file is implicitly defined by the extension of m_path. The file can only be created if it doesn't exist yet. After the file has been created successfully, the file is opened automatically for contents in streaming mode.

This means that only the methods:

  • WriteStreaming
  • WriteStreamingAsync
  • ReadStreaming
  • ReadStreamingAsync and not the methods Read() or Write() can be used with this file.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

virtual BOOLEAN File::Delete (   )  [pure virtual]
 

Deletes the file or directory. If the file is actually a directory, then it must be empty in order to be deleted. If the file or directory does not exist the method fails. The method succeeds if and only if the file or directory could successfully be deleted. This is a file operation, the file must not be open on call.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Exists (   )  const
 

Tells if the file exists, i.e. it is checked whether a file with the pathname of this object exists. The root directory always exists. For other pathnames the associated storage device is asked whether a file with the pathname of this object exists.

virtual BOOLEAN File::GetAccessDate (  Date &  date  )  const [inline, virtual]
 

If the access date of the file is available then date is set to it and TRUE is returned, otherwise FALSE is returned. The file need not be open. Please override this method for storage devices which support retrieving the date of the last file access.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Reimplemented in FatFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

virtual BOOLEAN File::GetAttributes (  Attributes &  attributes  )  const [inline, virtual]
 

Gets all the attributes of this file at once. If no attribute could be retrieved FALSE is returned. If at least one attribute could be retrieved TRUE is returned and argument attributes specifies for each attribute whether it could be retrieved or not. The file need not be open.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

UINT8 File::GetChunkSize (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns the chunk size to use for file operations. Some storage device drivers are implemented in a way that they block other tasks. To avoid this, a file operation can be split into smaller chunks and operates on these sequentially. Each operation on a small chunk still blocks, however, between operating the chunks, other tasks are given the opportunity to handle their messages, thereby avoiding unwanted blocking of other tasks and improving user experience. The chunk size is specified in terms of 4 KB blocks (i.e. 4096 bytes). Hence, to get the effective chunk size used in KB, multiply the returned value with 4.

Returns:
Chunk size in terms of 4 KB blocks (i.e. 4096 bytes).

virtual BOOLEAN File::GetCreationDate (  Date &  date  )  const [pure virtual]
 

If the creation date of the file is available then date is set to it and TRUE is returned, otherwise FALSE is returned.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

Returns the name of the file without directory information.

WString File::GetNativeDirectoryPathname (   )  const
 

Returns the pathname in native directory name format. The native directory name format may differ from storage device to storage device.

WString File::GetNativeFilePathname (   )  const
 

Returns the pathname in native file name format. The native file name format may differ from storage device to storage device.

virtual BOOLEAN File::GetNativeProperty (  UINT  prop_Id,
void *  val
)  const [inline, virtual]
 

Retrieves the native property identified by prop_Id via argument val. If the property is not supported by the native file (and therefore can't be retrieved) the method fails. The properties that the native file supports are defined by the derived class that implements the native file support. E.g., for knowing which properties a flash file supports look at the documentation of class FlashFileImp, there the respective property IDs are defined. It is crucial that the given property ID prop_Id and the receiving value val really match!

Parameters:
prop_Id ID of the native file property to retrieve, defined in the derived class that implements the native file support.
val Valid pointer to the value object that shall be set to the current value of the file property with id prop_Id.
Returns:
Tells if the file property could be retrieved.

Reimplemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, and RootFileImp.

const Path & File::GetPath (   )  const
 

Returns the path of the file.

Returns the pathname of the file.

virtual BOOLEAN File::GetSize (  UINT32 &  size  )  const [pure virtual]
 

If the file size can be retrieved then size is set to the actual file size in bytes and TRUE is returned, otherwise FALSE is returned. The file need not be open.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

void File::MakePermanent (   ) 
 

If this file has been created as a temporary file the file is turned into a permanent one, otherwise nothing is done.

BOOLEAN File::Move (  const Pathname &  dest_pathname  )  [virtual]
 

Moves the file to pathname dest_pathname on the current storage device. The dest_pathname has to contain the target filename. Only specifying a directory where the file should be moved to is not allowed.

Parameters:
dest_path The path where to move this file to.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

virtual FileState& File::MyState (   )  [protected, pure virtual]
 

Returns the state of the file.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Open (  OpenMode  open_mode  )  [pure virtual]
 

Opens the file for reading and/or writing depending on open_mode. There are two open modes:

  • ReadOnlyMode and
  • ReadAndWriteMode.

Opening a file is only possible if the file exists and is currently closed, otherwise opening fails. If opened in ReadOnlyMode only reading the file is allowed, writing the file causes an assertion to fail. If opened in ReadAndWriteMode both reading and writing the file are allowed. Please close the file after contents operations by calling Close(). However, if the file is not closed explicitly then it will be closed automatically on destruction. Opening a directory is not allowed and will result in an assertion. An overriding method must call this base implementation at the end of its implementation if the file could be opened successfully to assure that the open mode, the internal file position, and the counter of open files get set properly.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::OpenStreaming (  OpenMode  open_mode  )  [pure virtual]
 

In difference to Open(), the file is opened in streaming mode. This means that only the methods:

  • WriteStreaming
  • WriteStreamingAsync
  • ReadStreaming
  • ReadStreamingAsync and not the methods Read() or Write() can be used.

Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::PrepareRename (  const WString &  new_name,
String &  new_native_name
)  const [protected]
 

Checks if new_name is a filename without any folders specified and if new_name is different from the current name. If so, TRUE is returned and new_native_name is set to the new pathname in native format, else FALSE is returned and the appropriate error code is set.

BOOLEAN File::Read (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  offset,
UINT32  max_count,
UINT32 &  bytes_read
) 
 

Reads up to max_count bytes from this file starting at offset and copies them to the provided buffer. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. If the read operation was successful then argument bytes_read is set to the actual number of bytes read. This number may differ from max_count due to reaching the end of file while reading. Therefore it is essential to check bytes_read if TRUE is returned! Take care that if you start reading at the end of the file, i.e. parameter offset is greater than or equal to the size of the file, this method sets bytes_read to 0 and returns TRUE, signaling end of file! Please see the following sample function for completely reading a file:

            static BOOLEAN ReadFile(const FilePtr &open_file)
            {
                ASSERT_DEBUG(open_file->IsOpen());

                // Define read buffer.
                const UINT buf_size = 128;
                CHAR buf[buf_size];

                // Define variables used for reading.
                UINT32 offset = 0;
                UINT32 bytes_read;
                BOOLEAN ok;

                // Read whole file in a loop.
                while ((ok = open_file->Read(buf, offset, buf_size, bytes_read)) &&
                    bytes_read != 0)
                {
                    // Use buf which is filled with valid data from index 0 to index
                    // (bytes_read - 1).
                    // ...

                    // Increase offset where to read next.
                    offset += bytes_read;
                }

                // ok is FALSE if a read error occurred, otherwise TRUE.
                return ok;
            }

If the read operation fails, use GetLastError() to investigate the error.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer where the bytes read have to be copied to. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least max_count bytes in size.
offset The zero-based position where to start reading the file.
max_count The number of bytes to read.
bytes_read Bytes actually read.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::Read (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  offset,
UINT32  count
) 
 

Reads exactly count bytes from this file starting at offset and copies them to the provided buffer. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. If the method could not succeed use method GetLastError() to investigate the problem.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer where the bytes read have to be copied to. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least count bytes in size.
offset The zero-based position where to start reading the file.
count The number of bytes to read.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::ReadCur (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  max_count,
UINT32 &  bytes_read
) 
 

Reads up to max_count bytes from this file starting at the current file position and copies them to the provided buffer. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. If the read operation was successful then argument bytes_read is set to the actual number of bytes read. This number may differ from max_count due to reaching the end of file while reading. Therefore it is essential to check bytes_read if TRUE is returned! Take care that if you start reading at the end of the file, i.e. the current file position is greater than or equal to the size of the file, this method sets bytes_read to 0 and returns TRUE, signaling end of file! Please see the following sample function for completely reading a file:

            static BOOLEAN ReadCurFile(const FilePtr &open_file)
            {
                ASSERT_DEBUG(open_file->IsOpen() && open_file->Tell() == 0);

                // Define read buffer.
                const UINT buf_size = 128;
                CHAR buf[buf_size];

                // Define variables used for reading.
                UINT32 bytes_read;
                BOOLEAN ok;

                // Read whole file in a loop.
                while ((ok = open_file->ReadCur(buf, buf_size, bytes_read)) &&
                    bytes_read != 0)
                {
                    // Use buf which is filled with valid data from index 0 to index
                    // (bytes_read - 1).
                    // ...
                }

                // ok is FALSE if a read error occurred, otherwise TRUE.
                return ok;
            }

If the read operation fails, use GetLastError() to investigate the error.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer where the bytes read have to be copied to. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least max_count bytes in size.
max_count The number of bytes to read.
bytes_read Bytes actually read.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::ReadCur (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count
) 
 

Reads exactly count bytes from this file starting at the current file position and copies them to the provided buffer. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. If the method could not succeed use method GetLastError() to investigate the problem.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer where the bytes read have to be copied to. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least count bytes in size.
count The number of bytes to read.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::ReadStreaming (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count,
UINT32 &  bytes_read
) 
 

Behaves exactly as the method Read() with the same parameter list. The differences to the Read method are:

  • this method only works on files, which are opened in streaming mode.
  • the read operation is fulfilled with an higher priority and therefore may return faster.

BOOLEAN File::ReadStreamingAsync (  void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count,
StreamingCallback 
) 
 

ReadStreamingAsync is the asynchronous pendant of ReadStreaming() The method returns immediately after his call and signalises later by calling the callback function /a StreamingCallback, that the read operation ended. An possible error code and the number of bytes read are returned as parameters of the callback function /a StreamingCallback.

BOOLEAN File::Rename (  const WString &  new_name  )  [pure virtual]
 

Renames the file or directory to new_name. If the file or directory does not exist the method fails. Argument new_name is the file name including the file extension (if any) but without any leading directories. The MIME type of the renamed file is defined by the extension of the new name, if none exists it has general type. If the new name is equal to the old name the method fails. The method succeeds if and only if the file or directory really was renamed. Subclasses have to first check if the new file name is different to the actual one, then physically rename the file, and finally call this base method for changing the name which is controlled within this base class. This base method never fails. For a sample implementation see FlashFileImp::Rename(). This is a file operation, the file must not be open on call.

Parameters:
new_name New name of the file including the file extension (if any). No directory segments are allowed.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Resize (  UINT32  new_size,
UINT32  copy_buf_size = c_copy_buf_size
)  [virtual]
 

Resizes the file to contain new_size bytes. If the new size is less than the original size then the file is truncated. If the new size is bigger than the original size then the newly created part of the file is not initialized and has to be written to be in defined state. Emptying a file by resizing it to size 0 is allowed. This default implementation uses a temporary file for resizing. Override this method if resizing is explicitly supported by the derived file class. This is a file operation, the file must not be open on call.

Parameters:
new_size The new size of the file.
copy_buf_size The size of the internally used copy buffer, if used at all. The size of this buffer may significantly affect the performance of this operation.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Reimplemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

BOOLEAN File::Seek (  INT32  offset,
SeekOrigin  origin
) 
 

Repositions the current file position to the position that is offset bytes from origin. The next ReadCur() or WriteCur() operation takes place at the new position.

Parameters:
offset Number of bytes from origin.
origin Initial position.

virtual BOOLEAN File::SetArchive (  BOOLEAN  archive  )  [pure virtual]
 

Sets the archive flag.

Parameters:
archive If TRUE then the file is an archive.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

void File::SetChunkSize (  UINT8  size,
BOOLEAN  send_progress_messages = FALSE
) 
 

Sets chunk size to use for operation in chunk mode. This value is specified in terms of 4 KB blocks (i.e. 4096 bytes). Hence, to get the effective chunk size used in KB, multiply value size with 4. To disable chunk mode operation, provide 0 as chunk size. To use the recommended chunk size, specify the value which is defined as the default chunk size by the associated storage device. Argument send_progress_messages defines whether progress messages shall be sent or not. Progress messages can be used to implement a progress bar indicating the progress of the chunk mode operation.

See also:
StorageDevice::GetDefaultChunkSize()

virtual BOOLEAN File::SetHidden (  BOOLEAN  hidden  )  [pure virtual]
 

Sets the hidden flag.

Parameters:
hidden If TRUE then the file is hidden.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

virtual BOOLEAN File::SetNativeProperty (  UINT  prop_Id,
const void *  val
)  [inline, virtual]
 

Sets the native property identified by prop_Id to value val. If the property is not supported by the native file (and therefore can't be set) the method fails. The properties that the native file supports are defined by the derived class that implements the native file support. E.g., for knowing which properties a flash file supports look at the documentation of class FlashFileImp, there the respective property IDs are defined. It is crucial that the given property ID prop_Id and the passed value val really match!

Parameters:
prop_Id ID of the native file property to set, defined in the derived class that implements the native file support.
val Valid pointer to the value that shall be set for file property with id prop_Id.
Returns:
Tells if the file property could be set.

Reimplemented in FlashFileImp, and RootFileImp.

virtual BOOLEAN File::SetReadOnly (  BOOLEAN  read_only  )  [pure virtual]
 

Sets the read only flag.

Parameters:
read_only If TRUE then the file is set to read only mode.

Implemented in FatFileImp, FlashFileImp, RamFileImp, and RootFileImp.

void File::SetTemporary (   )  [protected]
 

Sets the file to be deleted on destruction.

BOOLEAN File::Split (  UINT32  offset,
const Pathname &  new_file,
UINT32  copy_buf_size = c_copy_buf_size
)  [virtual]
 

Splits the contents of this file at offset. The first half of the file remains in this file, the second half of the file will be stored in new_file. Pathname new_file specifies an existing directory with a new filename, i.e. the directory must exist but the file must not exist, otherwise the method fails. If new_file specifies this file nothing is done and FALSE is returned. The specified offset must be greater than 0 and lower than the current size of the file minus 1, otherwise an assertion holds. This file must exist, must not be a directory and must not be open, otherwise an assertion holds.

Parameters:
offset Number of bytes from origin where to split the file.
new_file The pathname of the file which will store the second half of the file.
copy_buf_size The size of the internally used copy buffer, if used at all. The size of this buffer may significantly affect the performance of this operation.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Reimplemented in RootFileImp.

UINT32 File::Tell (   ) 
 

Returns the current file position where the next ReadCur() or WriteCur() operation takes place.

BOOLEAN File::Write (  const void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  offset,
UINT32  count
) 
 

Writes the specified count bytes to the file starting at position offset. The bytes are read from buffer. The filesize is increased if required. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. On error please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer containing the bytes to write to the file. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least count bytes in size.
offset Defines the position within the file where to start writing the specified bytes.
count The number of bytes that should be written from the buffer to the file.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::WriteCur (  const void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count
) 
 

Writes the specified count bytes to the file starting at the current file position. The bytes are read from buffer. The filesize is increased if required. This is a contents operation. The file must be opened before. On error please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

Parameters:
buffer The pointer to the buffer containing the bytes to write to the file. It must be a valid pointer and the buffer must be at least count bytes in size.
count The number of bytes that should be written from the buffer to the file.
Returns:
Flag indicating success. Please call GetLastError() to get an error code.

BOOLEAN File::WriteStreaming (  const void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count
) 
 

Behaves exactly as the method Write() with the same parameter list. The differences to the Write method are:

  • this method only works on files, which are opened in streaming mode.
  • the write operation is fulfilled with an higher priority and therefore may return faster.

BOOLEAN File::WriteStreamingAsync (  const void HUGE *  buffer,
UINT32  count,
StreamingCallback  callback_func
) 
 

WriteStreamingAsync is the asynchronous pendant of WriteStreaming() The method returns immediately after his call and signalises later by calling the callback function /a StreamingCallback, that the write operation ended. An possible error code is returned as parameter of the callback function /a StreamingCallback.
